Family inheritances are often set up in trusts, passed down after death using money that has already been taxed. This is not some kind of tax loophole, but a way to ensure that minors and dependents receive their money responsibly. Trusts must distribute all income each year to beneficiaries and anything left over is taxed at a high rate. The rules around trust taxes have recently changed, making them less desirable from a tax perspective. It's hypocritical to criticize these trusts, as they can be used by anyone, not just the wealthy. There are plenty of ways for farmers and business owners to legally transfer wealth to their families without incurring huge tax penalties. The idea that proposed changes will greatly impact the wealthy is unrealistic. Smart individuals will always find legal ways to protect their assets.

Estate Planning Trusts are often set up as part of a person's will, using taxed funds. This is not a tax loophole. Instead of leaving money directly to young children or grandchildren, a trust is established where all income must be distributed to beneficiaries each year by a designated individual - any income that remains within the trust is taxed at the highest rate. Recent changes in trust tax laws have made this option less advantageous from a tax standpoint. Sheer is being hypocritical on this matter. And anyone has the ability to establish such trusts after they pass away.
